bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, September 18, 1940

div1.p: Hench describes his research on Lazear, the Camp Lazear location, and Moran's and Kissinger's experiences. He requests a copy of Peabody's bibliography.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, September 18, 1940
div1.opener:
September 18, 1940
Dr. J. E. Peabody
281 Lowell Ave.
Newtonville, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Peabody:
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how much I appreciate your sending me your pamphlet
“The Conquest of Yellow Fever” and the additional notes. I have collected quite
a lot of new stuff. You will be interested to know that I found that Lazear
secretly had himself bitten deliberately and died of true experimental yellow fever.
I hope to announce my facts on the occasion of the dedication of the Lazear
Memorial Building at Washington and Jefferson College, Washington, Pa., October 26.

I also found while I was in Cuba that the government had chosen the wrong
site of Camp Lazear. After some trouble, Moran and I relocated the true site. The
government objects to our findings, but we are absolutely right and I am sure can
prove it to anyone who will accept responsible proof. I will be glad to send you a
copy of my paper or papers after they are finished.

I notice that in one of your reports which you sent me, you advised that
someone get the story of Kissinger and Moran while they were alive. I have already
done this and hope to publish these stories, under their own names. They needed
considerable editing and checking, as their memories were somewhat faulty. Although
both are fine men, each has lived the story so much that unconsciously he has strayed
a little from the truth. Curiously, Kissinger's original story is that he went first
to Reed, and Moran went a few days later. Moran's letter to you indicated that he
went first and Kissinger went the next day, each going alone. Moran's last version
was that they went together and that he (Moran) was the spokesman. This is relatively
unimportant as far as outsiders are concerned, but it is just one of the things I have
had to straighten out.

May I ask you what all you sent to the library in Baltimore. I am going
to write them and see if I can have some of the material made available for me in
photostatic form. At the end of your pamphlet, on page 33, you say that a much more
complete bibliography on yellow fever has been prepared with the help of the library
of the American Museum of Natural History. I wrote to the librarian, but he did not
send me this bibliography. Do you happen to have a copy which I could keep or copy?
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
